question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: Who was Marlon Rodrigues Garcia's employer as of 2046?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

content.source_1:
Title: The Quantum Connection: Unraveling the Research Trail of Marlon Rodrigues Garcia

In the vibrant city of São Carlos, Brazil, a hub of scientific inquiry thrived within the walls of the São Carlos Institute of Physics at the University of São Paulo. It was here that Marlon Rodrigues Garcia, a brilliant researcher, left an indelible mark on the world of physics. This narrative delves into the life and work of Garcia, weaving together the threads of evidence that confirm his affiliation with the esteemed research institute. Chapter 1: The Early Years

Marlon Rodrigues Garcia's fascination with the mysteries of the universe began at a young age. Growing up in Brazil, he was drawn to the works of renowned physicists, such as Albert Einstein and Niels Bohr. His curiosity and passion for discovery led him to pursue a degree in physics from the University of São Paulo. It was during his undergraduate studies that Garcia's talent and dedication caught the attention of the faculty, paving the way for his future research endeavors. Chapter 2: The São Carlos Connection

In 2005, Garcia joined the São Carlos Institute of Physics at the University of São Paulo as a research assistant. This marked the beginning of a fruitful collaboration that would span several years. During his tenure, Garcia worked under the guidance of Dr. Maria Cristina Barbosa, a prominent physicist in the field of condensed matter physics. Together, they explored the properties of superconducting materials, publishing several papers in esteemed scientific journals, including the Physical Review B. One such paper, titled "Superconducting Properties of YBCO Thin Films," co-authored by Garcia and Barbosa, was presented at the 2007 International Conference on Superconductivity in Rio de Janeiro. This research, funded by the Brazilian National Council for Scientific and Technological Development (CNPq), demonstrated Garcia's expertise in experimental physics and his ability to contribute to cutting-edge research. Chapter 3: The Research Trail

Garcia's work at the São Carlos Institute of Physics was not limited to superconductivity. He also delved into the realm of quantum computing, collaborating with Dr. Antonio Carlos Santos on a project funded by the São Paulo Research Foundation (FAPESP). Their research focused on the development of quantum algorithms for solving complex optimization problems.
content.source_2: In the year 2026, the world was on the cusp of a medical revolution. Advances in technology and research had brought humanity to the doorstep of unprecedented breakthroughs in healthcare. Amidst this backdrop of innovation, a young and ambitious researcher named Marlon Rodrigues Garcia was about to embark on a journey that would change the course of his life forever. It was October 2026 when Marlon first walked through the doors of the prestigious Children's Hospital of Philadelphia, a beacon of hope for countless families seeking medical care for their little ones. With a spring in his step and a fire in his belly, Marlon was eager to contribute his skills to the esteemed institution. As he began his tenure, he was struck by the hospital's commitment to pushing the boundaries of pediatric medicine. The early years flew by in a whirlwind of research papers, clinical trials, and late-night lab sessions. Marlon's passion and dedication earned him recognition among his peers, and he quickly rose through the ranks. His work focused on developing novel treatments for rare genetic disorders, and his findings began to make waves in the medical community. As the years went by, Marlon became an integral part of the hospital's research team. He formed lasting bonds with his colleagues, and together, they tackled some of the most pressing health challenges facing children worldwide. The hospital's corridors, once unfamiliar, became a second home to Marlon, where he spent countless hours pouring over data, conducting experiments, and collaborating with his team. The 2030s brought about a new era of technological advancements, and Marlon was at the forefront of embracing these innovations. He pioneered the use of artificial intelligence in pediatric research, leveraging machine learning algorithms to identify patterns and predict outcomes. His work led to a significant reduction in mortality rates for children with certain genetic conditions, earning him international acclaim. As the years turned into decades, Marlon's reputation as a leading researcher in his field continued to grow. He became a sought-after speaker at conferences, a trusted advisor to governments, and a mentor to a new generation of scientists. Through it all, he remained humble, grounded, and committed to his work at the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia. December 2044 marked a bittersweet milestone for Marlon. After nearly two decades of dedicated service, he decided it was time to pass the torch to the next generation of researchers.
